item.title: Claude Code Board: Use Claude Code on Kanban WebUI
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code Board is a web-based Kanban-style management interface designed specifically for the Claude Code CLI. If you are a power user of Claude Code, you might find yourself juggling multiple terminal windows to handle different tasks concurrently. Claude Code Board solves this by providing a unified, visual interface to manage these sessions.

It aims to enhance the developer experience by allowing concurrent management of multiple AI coding sessions with real-time status tracking (idle, processing, completed, error).

Features

Section titled “Features”

Multi-Session Management

Section titled “Multi-Session Management”

Run multiple Claude Code instances simultaneously. The Kanban board allows you to see the status of each session at a glance—whether it’s idle, processing, or completed.

Advanced AI Workflows

Section titled “Advanced AI Workflows”
  • Agent Integration: Load custom Claude agents directly from your ~/.claude/agents/ directory.
  • Workflow Stages: Utilize pre-configured stages like Code Review, Bug Fixing, and Feature Development to structure your work.
  • Smart Prompting: Automatically inject agent instructions and custom templates to streamline your interaction with the AI.

Project Organization

Section titled “Project Organization”

Group your sessions under “Work Items,” tag them by project or topic, and automatically manage workspace paths. This keeps your work organized conceptually, not just by terminal ID.

Enhanced UI/UX

Section titled “Enhanced UI/UX”
  • WebSocket-powered chat: Real-time updates and interaction.
  • Notifications: Windows Toast notifications alert you when a task is completed.
  • Message Filtering: Filter out “thinking” blocks or tool use logs to focus on the conversation and results.
  • Session Recovery: Resume previous conversations with full context preservation.

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites and Installation”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Operating System: Windows 10/11
  • Runtime: Node.js (v18+)
  • Core Tool: Claude Code CLI installed globally (npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code)

Installation Steps

Section titled “Installation Steps”

  1. Clone the Repository

  2. Install Dependencies You need to install dependencies for the root, backend, and frontend.

  3. Start the Application

    • Option 1 (Windows): Simply run start.bat.
    • Option 2 (Manual): Run npm run dev:backend and npm run dev:frontend in separate terminals.

  4. Access: Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:5173.

Usage Scenarios

Section titled “Usage Scenarios”

Concurrent Development

Section titled “Concurrent Development”

Imagine you are working on a feature, but you also need to fix a critical bug and review a PR. Instead of opening three terminals and losing track of context, you can create three cards on the Claude Code Board: “Feature X”, “Bug Y”, and “PR Review Z”. You can switch between them easily and see their progress.

Agent-Based Workflows

Section titled “Agent-Based Workflows”

You can configure specialized agents (e.g., an “Architect” agent or a “Debugger” agent) by creating .md files in your agents directory. When starting a session, you can select the specific agent best suited for the task.

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  • Security: This tool is designed for local/personal use only. It does not have enterprise-grade security (encryption/auth) and should not be deployed to public networks.
  • Platform: Currently optimized for Windows.

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • Claude Code Board GitHub Repository

item.title: Alma: One Elegant Desktop App to Rule All Your AI Providers
item.content:encoded:
The AI Provider Juggling Problem

Section titled “The AI Provider Juggling Problem”

If you’re like most AI power users, your workflow probably looks something like this:

  • ChatGPT tab for quick conversations
  • Claude tab for coding and analysis
  • Gemini tab for Google integration tasks
  • DeepSeek tab when you need cost-effective alternatives
  • A growing collection of API keys scattered across different tools

Sound familiar? You’re not alone. Managing multiple AI providers has become the new “too many browser tabs” problem.

Enter Alma — an elegant desktop solution that brings order to this chaos.

What is Alma?

Section titled “What is Alma?”

Alma is a beautifully designed macOS desktop application that serves as your unified command center for AI. Instead of switching between web interfaces, you access all your AI providers through one clean, intuitive interface.

Think of it as the universal remote for AI — one interface, multiple brains.

Who Built This?

Section titled “Who Built This?”

Alma comes from yetone, the same developer behind OpenAI Translator — a wildly popular project with 23.1k+ GitHub stars. That project evolved from a Chrome extension into a multi-platform desktop app, demonstrating yetone’s ability to build polished, production-ready tools.

This pedigree matters. Alma isn’t a weekend project — it’s built by someone with proven experience delivering AI-powered desktop applications that people actually use daily.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

Unified Chat Interface

Section titled “Unified Chat Interface”

A clean, intuitive chat interface that brings all your AI conversations together:

  • Markdown rendering for beautifully formatted responses
  • Code highlighting with syntax awareness
  • Real-time streaming responses as they’re generated
  • Dark/light theme toggle with smooth View Transitions API animations

Intelligent Memory System

Section titled “Intelligent Memory System”

Alma remembers context across conversations:

  • User preferences persist between sessions
  • Conversation context carries forward
  • Dedicated memory management panel for organization
  • View, organize, and prune memories as needed

Web Search Integration

Section titled “Web Search Integration”

Built-in capability to access real-time information:

  • AI can retrieve live web data when answering
  • No need to manually paste URLs or context
  • Current, accurate answers powered by actual web data

Advanced Tool Use

Section titled “Advanced Tool Use”

Beyond chat, Alma enables AI to perform complex tasks:

  • Mathematical calculations
  • Data analysis operations
  • Intelligent tool integration

Supported AI Providers

Section titled “Supported AI Providers”
ProviderStatus
OpenAI (GPT-4, etc.)Supported

DeepSeekSupported
Custom APIsSupported

This provider-agnostic approach means you’re never locked in. Use whatever model fits your task — whether that’s GPT-4 for creative work, Claude for analysis, or DeepSeek for cost-conscious inference.

Platform Status

Section titled “Platform Status”

Currently Available:

  • macOS Apple Silicon (.dmg)
  • macOS Intel (.dmg)

Coming Soon:

  • Windows
  • Linux

Note: Only macOS versions are currently tested and guaranteed to work. Windows and Linux support is in development.

Why Alma Matters

Section titled “Why Alma Matters”

1. Provider Flexibility

Section titled “1. Provider Flexibility”

Different models excel at different tasks. Claude might be your go-to for code, while GPT-4 shines at creative writing. Alma lets you switch contexts without switching apps.

2. API Cost Control

Section titled “2. API Cost Control”

By using your own API keys, you control costs directly. No middleman markup, no subscription surprises.

3. Privacy-First Design

Section titled “3. Privacy-First Design”

As a desktop application using your own API keys, your conversations don’t route through third-party services. The data stays between you and your chosen provider.

4. Memory Continuity

Section titled “4. Memory Continuity”

Unlike web interfaces that lose context, Alma’s memory system maintains continuity across sessions — making it feel less like a tool and more like a persistent assistant.

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”
  1. Visit alma.now
  2. Download the appropriate macOS version (Apple Silicon or Intel)
  3. Configure your API keys for preferred providers
  4. Start chatting with unified access to multiple AI models

The Bottom Line

Section titled “The Bottom Line”

Alma represents a shift from AI as scattered web services to AI as unified desktop infrastructure.

For users who regularly switch between multiple AI providers, this consolidation isn’t just convenient — it’s a workflow transformation. One app, multiple models, persistent memory, and an interface designed for daily use.

If you’re tired of juggling browser tabs and want a more sophisticated approach to AI provider management, Alma deserves a spot on your dock.

item.title: Beyond Technical Skills: What Really Matters for AI Software Engineers in 2025
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

When we talk about AI Software Engineers, most people immediately think of deep learning frameworks, Python proficiency, or years of experience with machine learning models. However, after analyzing real job postings and industry trends, I’ve discovered something profound: the qualities that truly differentiate successful AI engineers aren’t purely technical—they’re fundamentally human.

Let me share a recent job posting that crystallizes this insight perfectly.

The Job That Reveals Everything

Section titled “The Job That Reveals Everything”

Here’s a real AI Software Engineer position that caught my attention:

Job Responsibilities

Section titled “Job Responsibilities”

Responsible for R&D of AI products and services, designing and developing systems around business scenarios, providing solutions that meet business needs, and delivering reliable, stable, and scalable business systems quickly, cost-effectively, and continuously.

Basic Requirements

Section titled “Basic Requirements”
  • Bachelor’s degree or above in Computer Science, Communications, or related fields
  • Proficiency in at least one programming language: Java, Python, Go, TypeScript, etc.
  • Hands-on experience in AI-driven autonomous development products and services, able to effectively integrate AI capabilities into actual workflows
  • Good engineering practices, with fundamental pursuit of code quality, system stability, and maintainability

But Here’s What’s Really Important — The Soft Skill Requirements

Section titled “But Here’s What’s Really Important — The Soft Skill Requirements”
  1. Strong Sense of Responsibility: Take ownership of delivery results, continuously follow up on issues until closed
  2. Curiosity and Learning Ability: Stay sensitive to new technologies and tools, willing to proactively explore and quickly get up to speed
  3. Practical Execution Ability: Can quickly transform ideas into runnable, verifiable systems or features
  4. Planning Ability: Can reasonably decompose work tasks, autonomously evolve plans, and manage time arrangements
  5. Communication and Sharing Awareness: Willing to exchange technical solutions and experiences, possess cross-role collaboration capabilities

Why Soft Skills Outweigh Hard Skills in the AI Era

Section titled “Why Soft Skills Outweigh Hard Skills in the AI Era”

The Paradox of AI Development

Section titled “The Paradox of AI Development”

Here’s the irony: as AI becomes more capable of writing code, the value of pure coding skills diminishes. What AI cannot replicate are the uniquely human qualities:

  • Judgment — knowing when to apply AI and when human insight is needed
  • Responsibility — taking ownership of outcomes, not just outputs
  • Curiosity — asking “why” and “what if” rather than just “how”

Industry Data Supports This Shift

Section titled “Industry Data Supports This Shift”

According to IEEE Spectrum’s 2025 AI Jobs report, as tools like GitHub Copilot become adopted, the skill mix is shifting toward “uniquely human skills, like ethical reasoning or leadership.”

DataCamp’s analysis highlights that AI engineers need strong communication skills to “effectively communicate complex AI concepts to non-technical stakeholders.” This isn’t optional—it’s essential.

The Six Essential Qualities Decoded

Section titled “The Six Essential Qualities Decoded”

1. Strong Sense of Responsibility (责任心强)

Section titled “1. Strong Sense of Responsibility (责任心强)”

What it means: You don’t just write code—you own the outcome. When something breaks at 2 AM, you’re already investigating, not waiting for someone to assign you the ticket.

In practice:

  • Following issues through complete lifecycle, not just “throwing code over the wall”
  • Proactively monitoring systems you’ve built
  • Taking accountability for both successes and failures

Why AI can’t replace this: AI can generate code, but it cannot feel the weight of a production incident or the satisfaction of delivering real value to users.

2. Curiosity and Learning Ability (好奇心与学习能力)

Section titled “2. Curiosity and Learning Ability (好奇心与学习能力)”

What it means: The AI field moves at breakneck speed. What was state-of-the-art six months ago is now baseline. You must be intrinsically motivated to learn, not because your manager assigns a training course.

In practice:

  • Experimenting with new tools (Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot) on weekends
  • Reading research papers, not just documentation
  • Asking “why does this work?” not just “how do I use it?”

The compound effect: Anthropic’s best practices emphasize that working with AI agents is a skill that develops over time. The curiosity to iterate and improve separates novices from experts.

3. Practical Execution Ability (实践与执行能力)

Section titled “3. Practical Execution Ability (实践与执行能力)”

What it means: Ideas are worthless without execution. Can you transform a concept into a working prototype in days, not months?

In practice:

  • Building MVPs to validate hypotheses quickly
  • Knowing when “good enough” is actually good enough
  • Shipping iteratively rather than waiting for perfection

The AI amplification: With tools like AI coding assistants, execution speed has become a superpower. According to JetBrains’ guidelines, developers who can effectively guide AI agents ship 10x faster than those who code everything manually.

4. Planning Ability (规划能力)

Section titled “4. Planning Ability (规划能力)”

What it means: Breaking down complex problems into manageable chunks, sequencing work effectively, and managing time realistically.

In practice:

  • Decomposing a feature into specific, testable tasks
  • Knowing dependencies and critical paths
  • Estimating realistically (not optimistically)

Why this matters with AI: Medium’s guide on agent workflows emphasizes using “Plan–Act–Reflect” workflows. The clearer your structure, the better your AI agent performs.

5. Communication and Sharing Awareness (沟通与分享意识)

Section titled “5. Communication and Sharing Awareness (沟通与分享意识)”

What it means: Technical excellence in isolation is worthless. Can you explain your decisions to non-technical stakeholders? Can you mentor junior developers? Can you write documentation that others actually want to read?

In practice:

  • Writing clear, concise documentation
  • Participating in code reviews constructively
  • Sharing learnings in team meetings or blog posts

The multiplier effect: A developer who can communicate effectively multiplies their impact across the entire organization. Knowledge shared is knowledge amplified.

6. The Hidden Sixth Quality: Adaptability

Section titled “6. The Hidden Sixth Quality: Adaptability”

Though not explicitly listed, there’s an implicit requirement threading through all the others: adaptability. The willingness to change tools, approaches, and even mental models as the AI landscape evolves.

Comparative Analysis: Traditional vs. AI-Era Engineer

Section titled “Comparative Analysis: Traditional vs. AI-Era Engineer”
DimensionTraditional Software EngineerAI-Era Software Engineer
Primary ToolIDE + Search EngineIDE + AI Assistant + Agent
Code SourceMostly self-writtenHybrid (human-AI collaboration)
DebuggingRead stack tracesPrompt AI to analyze
Learning CurveMaster one stack deeplyContinuously adapt to new tools
Key DifferentiatorTechnical depthJudgment + Communication + Execution
Career GrowthSenior IC or ManagerAgent Orchestrator + Technical Lead

Practical Recommendations

Section titled “Practical Recommendations”

For Job Seekers

Section titled “For Job Seekers”
  1. Build a Portfolio of AI-Assisted Projects: Show that you can effectively leverage AI tools, not just code from scratch
  2. Document Your Decision-Making Process: Blog about why you chose certain approaches, not just what you built
  3. Demonstrate Cross-Functional Collaboration: Highlight projects where you worked with designers, PMs, and business stakeholders
  4. Show Continuous Learning: Your GitHub should have recent experiments, not just code from years ago

For Hiring Managers

Section titled “For Hiring Managers”
  1. Redesign Interview Questions: Ask candidates how they’d approach problems with AI assistance, not just algorithmic puzzles
  2. Evaluate Soft Skills Explicitly: Structured behavioral interviews for responsibility, curiosity, and communication
  3. Value Side Projects: As Boris Cherny (Claude Code creator) discovered, side projects often reveal true capability better than resume credentials

For Current Engineers Looking to Level Up

Section titled “For Current Engineers Looking to Level Up”
  1. Pick One AI Tool and Master It: Whether it’s Claude Code, Cursor, or GitHub Copilot, deep expertise beats broad familiarity
  2. Practice Explaining Technical Concepts: Start a blog, give internal talks, or mentor juniors
  3. Take Ownership of Something End-to-End: Volunteer for a project where you’re responsible from design to production

The Future is Human + AI

Section titled “The Future is Human + AI”

The AI Software Engineer of 2025 isn’t someone who competes with AI—they’re someone who orchestrates AI to achieve outcomes neither could accomplish alone.

The job posting we analyzed gets it exactly right: technical competence is the baseline. What separates exceptional candidates from merely qualified ones are those six qualities that no AI can replicate:

  • Responsibility that drives outcomes
  • Curiosity that fuels innovation
  • Execution that ships products
  • Planning that manages complexity
  • Communication that multiplies impact
  • Adaptability that ensures longevity

The future belongs to engineers who embrace AI as a partner while cultivating the irreplaceable human qualities that make great software possible.

References

Section titled “References”
  • AI Engineer Job Outlook 2025 - 365 Data Science
  • The 14 Essential AI Engineer Skills - DataCamp
  • AI Jobs in 2025 - IEEE Spectrum
  • Claude Code Best Practices - Anthropic
  • Building With AI Coding Agents - Medium
  • Coding Guidelines for AI Agents - JetBrains
  • 10 Software Engineering Skills for AI Economy - Quantic

The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling

Section titled “The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling”

Creating professional infographics has always been a time-consuming process. Designers spend hours in tools like Figma, Illustrator, or Canva, manually arranging elements, adjusting colors, and ensuring visual consistency.

For developers and data scientists, the gap between raw data and compelling visual narratives feels even wider. You have the information — but turning it into something shareable and engaging requires skills that extend beyond code.

What if you could generate beautiful infographics with just text and data?

Enter AntV Infographic — Ant Group’s open-source, declarative infographic visualization engine that makes professional visual content creation accessible to everyone.

What is AntV Infographic?

Section titled “What is AntV Infographic?”

AntV Infographic is a next-generation declarative infographic visualization engine from the AntV team (part of Ant Group). With a carefully designed infographic syntax, it can quickly and flexibly render high-quality infographics, making information presentation more efficient and data storytelling simpler.

The framework is built with AI-native workflows in mind — its syntax is optimized for large language model generation, and it supports real-time streaming rendering.

Key metrics:

  • 200+ built-in templates for immediate use
  • SVG output for pixel-perfect quality at any size
  • MIT licensed and fully open source

Section titled “AI-Friendly Design”

Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web

Section titled “Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web”

🦞 EXFOLIATE! EXFOLIATE! — That’s the playful battlecry of Clawdis, an open-source personal AI assistant created by Peter Steinberger (@steipete). Unlike cloud-hosted AI services, Clawdis runs on your own devices, connecting to the messaging platforms you already use daily: WhatsApp, Telegram, and Web.

What is Clawdis?

Section titled “What is Clawdis?”

Clawdis is a local-first control plane for your personal AI assistant. Think of it as the infrastructure that lets you interact with an AI agent through:

  • WhatsApp — Send a message, get an intelligent response
  • Telegram — Bot-based conversations via the Telegram Bot API
  • WebChat — Browser-based interface for desktop use
  • macOS app — Menu bar control with voice wake and push-to-talk
  • iOS node — Canvas surface with voice trigger forwarding

The name “Clawdis” is a clever portmanteau: CLAW + TARDIS — because every space lobster needs a time-and-space machine!

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Multi-Surface Inbox

Section titled “1. Multi-Surface Inbox”

Clawdis brings your AI assistant to wherever you already communicate. No need to switch to a dedicated app — just message from WhatsApp or Telegram, and your assistant responds.

2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk

Section titled “2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk”

On macOS and iOS, Clawdis supports:

  • Voice wake — Say the wake word and start talking

  • Local speech recognition — Privacy-preserving, on-device processing

3. Live Canvas

Section titled “3. Live Canvas”

A visual workspace that you can control from the agent. The Canvas renders live content and supports A2UI (Agent-to-UI) communication for rich interactive experiences.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?

Section titled “Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?”

Clawdis is agent-agnostic but was designed around Pi (an RPC-based agent runtime) and commonly uses Claude models. You can configure your preferred AI provider.

Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?”

Clawdis is designed as a single-user, personal assistant. For multi-user scenarios, you’d need to run separate instances.

Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?

Section titled “Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?”

Clawdis uses the WhatsApp Web protocol via Baileys. Use responsibly and at your own risk.

Q: How do I add custom skills?

Section titled “Q: How do I add custom skills?”

Create a new folder in ~/clawd/skills/<skill-name>/ with a SKILL.md file describing the skill’s capabilities and instructions.

Are you tired of maintaining the same UI components across multiple JavaScript frameworks? Meet Mitosis by Builder.io - the revolutionary tool that lets you write components once and compile them to React, Vue, Angular, Svelte, Solid, Qwik, and many more frameworks.

What is Mitosis?

Section titled “What is Mitosis?”

Mitosis is an open-source compiler that transforms JSX components into fully functional components for any major JavaScript framework. By writing your UI components once in a framework-agnostic JSX syntax, you can deploy them across any platform without rewriting code for each framework.

Mitosis shines for teams maintaining design systems across multiple frameworks. Instead of duplicating component logic and styles for each framework version, write it once and let Mitosis handle the translations.

item.title: Boris Cherny: How the Creator of Claude Code Grew His Career from Meta to Anthropic
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Behind every revolutionary product is a story of personal growth, strategic thinking, and relentless curiosity. Boris Cherny, the creator of Claude Code at Anthropic, exemplifies this truth. His journey from startups to venture capital, through a decade at Meta (Facebook/Instagram), to leading one of the most impactful AI developer tools demonstrates key principles that any engineer can apply.

This article distills Boris’s career insights, revealing how he went from a mid-level engineer to principal at Meta, and finally to creating Claude Code—a tool that now writes 80-90% of its own codebase.

The Unconventional Path

Section titled “The Unconventional Path”

Boris started his first startup at 18, worked at a hedge fund, and notably has no CS degree—he studied economics before dropping out to pursue startups. His trajectory proves that programming is a practical skill learned on the job, not in classrooms.

Key milestones at Meta (2012-2022):

  • IC4 (Mid-level): Joined “under-leveled” working on Messenger-Groups integration
  • IC5-IC6: Led Groups web migration; created the Undux state management library
  • IC7 (Senior Staff): Drove Public Groups feature with complex data model migrations
  • IC8 (Principal): Scoped work for hundreds of engineers; led Instagram’s Python-to-Hack migration

Five Principles for Career Growth

Section titled “Five Principles for Career Growth”

1. Design for the Model Six Months from Now

Section titled “1. Design for the Model Six Months from Now”

In the fast-evolving AI landscape, don’t build for current model capabilities—design for future ones.

“Don’t build for today’s model, build for the model six months from now.” — Ben Mann, Boris’s manager at Anthropic

This forward-thinking approach explains why Claude Code initially felt underwhelming but became transformative after Claude 4 series launched. Early products may have mediocre experiences, but when new models drop, you achieve quantum leaps.

2. Discover Latent Demand

Section titled “2. Discover Latent Demand”

The most successful products don’t invent new behaviors—they satisfy hidden, existing ones.

Boris observed at Facebook that users were “abusing” Groups for commerce 40% of the time. This observation birthed Facebook Marketplace. Similarly, Dating emerged from observing how people were already using the platform for connections.

Lesson: Watch what users are hacking together with your existing features—that’s where product-market fit hides.

3. Side Projects Are Your Biggest Career Lever

Section titled “3. Side Projects Are Your Biggest Career Lever”

Through solving repeated pain points and promoting solutions as company-wide tools, Boris accumulated cross-team influence rapidly.

His “20% time” projects included:

  • Undux: A state management library for React
  • TypeScript Book & Meetup: Community building in the developer space
  • Lint Rule Automation: Turning repeated code review comments into automated checks
  • Large Dataset Testing Framework: Infrastructure benefiting thousands of engineers

“Better engineering is the easiest way to grow your network and gain influence as an engineer.”

4. Become a Generalist Who Breaks Swim Lanes

Section titled “4. Become a Generalist Who Breaks Swim Lanes”

High-impact engineers don’t just write code—they develop product sense, design ability, and user research skills.

At both Meta and Anthropic, there are no formal titles. Everyone is a “Member of Technical Staff” regardless of whether they’re an engineer, PM, or designer. This culture forces constant re-validation through execution rather than title.

“Just because you’re a product engineer doesn’t mean you can’t build infra.”

5. Common Sense Is Your Superpower

Section titled “5. Common Sense Is Your Superpower”

In complex organizations with historical baggage and process inertia, the most reliable decision-making framework is returning to basics:

  • What does the user actually need?
  • Does this make sense?

Rather than being led by organizational momentum, successful leaders constantly ask these fundamental questions.

The Claude Code Creation Story

Section titled “The Claude Code Creation Story”

Origin

Section titled “Origin”

Claude Code started as an accidental discovery during internal experiments at Anthropic. Boris’s manager pushed beyond autocomplete thinking, encouraging design for future model capabilities.

The Struggle

Section titled “The Struggle”

Initially, Boris only used Claude Code for about 10% of his work. The product wasn’t viable until Sonnet/Opus 4 launched in March 2024.

The Breakthrough

Section titled “The Breakthrough”

After model improvements, usage jumped to 50% of coding work. Today, 80-90% of Claude Code is written by Claude Code itself. Surprisingly, adoption spread beyond engineers to data scientists and sales teams—unexpected use cases the team hadn’t anticipated.

Hiring Philosophy: Look for “Side Quests”

Section titled “Hiring Philosophy: Look for “Side Quests””

Boris actively seeks engineers with curiosity beyond daily work:

“When I hire engineers, this is definitely something I look for… cool weekend projects, like someone who’s really into making kombucha.”

This signals growth mindset and intellectual curiosity—traits that separate good engineers from great ones.

Key Quotes for Your Career

Section titled “Key Quotes for Your Career”

On imposter syndrome:

“No one knows what they’re doing at any level. If you don’t feel it, you’re not pushing hard enough.”

On focus vs. breadth:

“Writing code anchors you to reality. Without it, you lose intuition quickly—dangerous place to be.”

On team dynamics:

“You never want to tell anyone what to do. Understand what they want, then present opportunity—it always works better.”

On organizational change:

“Just do it. Sometimes you need consensus, sometimes you act. Leaders juggle both constantly.”

Actionable Takeaways

Section titled “Actionable Takeaways”

  1. Stop chasing titles—pursue interesting problems and impact. Promotions follow naturally.

  2. Invest in side projects—even small automations that help your team compound into massive influence over time.

  3. Become the generalist—learn product, design, and user research alongside engineering. The most valuable engineers are those who can wear multiple hats.

  4. Apply common sense liberally—when lost in organizational complexity, ask “what does the user actually need?”

When working with Claude Code on complex projects, you’ve likely encountered the frustrating “context degradation” problem. After several compaction cycles, you’re essentially working with a summary of a summary of a summary. Signal degrades into noise, and Claude starts hallucinating context.

item.title: Breaking: Google Finally Lets You Change Your @gmail.com Address
item.content:encoded:
The Long-Awaited Feature Is Here

Section titled “The Long-Awaited Feature Is Here”

For years, Gmail users have been stuck with whatever email address they created—even if it was something embarrassing from their teenage years. That’s finally changing. Google is gradually rolling out the ability to change your @gmail.com address to a new @gmail.com address, and this is huge news for anyone who’s ever regretted their email username choice.

What’s New?

Section titled “What’s New?”

According to Google’s official support page, you can now:

  • Change your Gmail address from one @gmail.com to another @gmail.com
  • Keep all your data - photos, messages, emails, everything stays intact
  • Use both addresses - your old address becomes an alias that still receives emails
  • Sign in with either - both old and new addresses work for login

How It Works

Section titled “How It Works”

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDetails
Old Address HandlingBecomes a backup/alias address
Email ReceptionBoth addresses receive emails to same inbox
Data MigrationNo data loss - everything is preserved
Sign-in OptionsCan use either old or new address
OwnershipOld address remains yours permanently

Important Limitations

Section titled “Important Limitations”

Before you rush to change your address, here are the limitations:

  1. Maximum 3 new addresses: You can create up to 3 new Gmail addresses, giving your account a total of 4 addresses maximum
  2. 12-month cooldown: After changing, you can’t create a new Gmail address for 12 months
  3. Cannot delete new address: For 12 months after changing, you cannot delete your new address
  4. Old address stays: Your old address cannot be completely removed—it remains as a backup address
  5. No one else can use it: Your old address is permanently reserved for you

Step-by-Step Guide

Section titled “Step-by-Step Guide”

Step 1: Check If You Have Access

Section titled “Step 1: Check If You Have Access”

The feature is gradually rolling out, so not everyone has it yet. To check:

  1. Go to myaccount.google.com/google-account-email
  2. Sign in if prompted
  3. Click Personal info in the left navigation
  4. Click Email → Google Account email
  5. Look for “Change Google Account email” option
    • If you see it: You have access! Continue to Step 2
    • If you don’t see it: The feature isn’t available to you yet

Step 2: Review Potential Issues

Section titled “Step 2: Review Potential Issues”

Before changing, consider these scenarios:

  • Chromebook users: May need additional steps
  • “Sign in with Google” on third-party sites: Some sites may require re-authentication
  • Chrome Remote Desktop: Remote connections may need to be re-established
  • App settings: Some app settings may reset (similar to logging in on a new device)

Pro tip: Back up your important data before making the change!

Step 3: Make the Change

Section titled “Step 3: Make the Change”
  1. Enter your desired new username
  2. The username must be unique (not used by another Google account)
  3. Click Change email → Yes, change
  4. Follow the on-screen instructions

Once complete, your new email becomes your primary Google Account email, and your old one becomes a backup address.

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Can I switch back to my old address?

Section titled “Can I switch back to my old address?”

Yes! Your original address becomes a backup address. You can switch back anytime by:

  1. Go to myaccount.google.com
  2. Select Email → Google Account email
  3. Find your old address and select “Make this your Google Account email”

Will I lose any emails?

Section titled “Will I lose any emails?”

No. All data is preserved, including emails sent to your old address. Both addresses deliver to the same inbox.

Can I add/remove dots in my Gmail address?

Section titled “Can I add/remove dots in my Gmail address?”

Dots in Gmail are already ignored (john.doe@gmail.com = johndoe@gmail.com). However, you cannot change punctuation in your Google Account email name—if your email contains dots, they will continue to display.

What happens to calendar events I created?

Section titled “What happens to calendar events I created?”

Pre-existing activities (like calendar events) will still show your old email address. The change is not retroactive for historical data.

Can someone else claim my old address?

Section titled “Can someone else claim my old address?”

No. Your old address is permanently reserved for you. Even if you delete your Google account, no one else can use that address.

When Can You Get It?

Section titled “When Can You Get It?”

Google states the feature is “gradually rolling out to all users.” Based on reports from 9to5Google, the feature documentation first appeared in Hindi and is expanding to other regions. If you don’t have access yet, check back periodically.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Before Changing

Section titled “Before Changing”
  1. Document third-party logins: Note which sites use “Sign in with Google”
  2. Export your data: Use Google Takeout to backup
  3. Notify contacts: Let important contacts know about your address change
  4. Update recovery options: Ensure your phone number and recovery email are current

After Changing

Section titled “After Changing”
  1. Test both addresses: Send test emails to both old and new
  2. Re-authenticate apps: Some apps may need you to sign in again
  3. Update professional profiles: LinkedIn, GitHub, etc.
  4. Monitor for issues: Watch for any sign-in or service problems

Who Should (and Shouldn’t) Change

Section titled “Who Should (and Shouldn’t) Change”

Good Candidates

Section titled “Good Candidates”
  • Those with embarrassing or unprofessional email addresses
  • Users who changed their name (marriage, etc.)
  • People wanting a cleaner, more memorable address

Think Twice If

Section titled “Think Twice If”
  • Your current address works fine for your needs
  • You have extensive “Sign in with Google” integrations
  • You’re heavily using Chromebook or Chrome Remote Desktop

The Bottom Line

Section titled “The Bottom Line”

This is a game-changing feature that Gmail users have wanted for over 20 years. While there are limitations (only 3 changes, 12-month cooldowns), the ability to finally update that cringe-worthy email address from 2005 is a welcome addition.

Key takeaway: The feature is rolling out gradually. Check your Google Account settings periodically, and when you see the option, consider carefully whether a change makes sense for your situation.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Google Account Help - Change your Google Account email
  • 9to5Google - Google says it is ‘gradually rolling out’ option to change your @gmail.com address
  • Android Authority - You may finally be able to change your old, embarrassing Gmail address

item.title: Google's 68-Page Prompt Engineering Whitepaper: 10 Best Practices That Actually Work
item.content:encoded:
Google recently released a 68-page whitepaper on prompt engineering authored by Lee Boonstra, and it’s already being called “the best structured, most readable, and most example-rich guide to LLM prompting as of 2025.” Here are the 10 best practices distilled from this comprehensive guide.

Why This Whitepaper Matters

Section titled “Why This Whitepaper Matters”

LLMs are prediction engines, not reasoning engines. Every word you provide guides the model to predict the next token. Understanding this fundamental principle is the key to mastering prompt engineering.

Techniques may become outdated, but the underlying principles remain constant.

1. Provide Examples, Don’t Just State Requirements

Section titled “1. Provide Examples, Don’t Just State Requirements”

Few-shot prompting consistently outperforms zero-shot approaches. When you provide 3-5 examples, the model understands your expectations far better than any amount of explanation.

Why it works: Examples let the model capture the structure, tone, and format you want. Instead of explaining what “professional” means, show a professional response.

Example:

2. Keep It Simple

Section titled “2. Keep It Simple”

Use action verbs. Avoid obscure expressions. One clear sentence beats three vague paragraphs.

LLMs don’t need pleasantries or context padding. They need direct instructions.

Preferred verbs:

  • Analyze
  • Create
  • Generate
  • Identify
  • Summarize
  • Compare
  • Extract

Before: “I was hoping you could perhaps help me write something that might be useful for understanding the topic of machine learning, if that’s not too much trouble.”

After: “Summarize machine learning in 3 sentences for a non-technical audience.”

3. Specify Output Format Explicitly

Section titled “3. Specify Output Format Explicitly”

Vague instructions produce random results. If you want JSON, say JSON. If you want 500 words, say 500 words.

The more specific your format requirements, the more predictable your outputs.

Weak: “Generate a blog post about video game consoles.”

Strong: “Generate a 3-paragraph blog post about the history of video game consoles. Use conversational style. Each paragraph should be 4-6 sentences. Include one specific statistic per paragraph.”

Pro tip: Request JSON format for structured, processable responses that naturally limit hallucinations:

4. Use Instructions, Not Constraints

Section titled “4. Use Instructions, Not Constraints”

Tell the model what TO DO, not what NOT to do.

Negation is inherently ambiguous for language models. “Don’t be verbose” is less effective than “Limit response to 100 words.”

Avoid ThisDo This Instead
”Don’t list video game names""Only discuss the console, company, year, and sales figures"
"Don’t be wordy""Limit each paragraph to 3 sentences"
"Don’t make things up""If uncertain, respond with ‘I cannot verify this’”

The psychology: Models process positive instructions more reliably because they define a clear action space rather than an infinite exclusion zone.

5. Control Token Length

Section titled “5. Control Token Length”

Cost scales linearly with tokens. Generating 1000 words costs 10x more than generating 100 words.

Always set explicit length constraints when token efficiency matters.

Techniques:

  • “Limit output to 80 characters”
  • “Explain in a tweet-length message”
  • “Respond in exactly 3 bullet points”
  • “Maximum 50 tokens”

Bonus: Token limits also force conciseness, often improving output quality.

6. Use Variables for Reusable Templates

Section titled “6. Use Variables for Reusable Templates”

Extract changeable elements into variables. One well-crafted template can be reused hundreds of times.

Benefits:

  • Consistency across multiple queries
  • Easier A/B testing
  • Programmatic prompt generation
  • Version control friendly

7. Experiment With Different Input Formats

Section titled “7. Experiment With Different Input Formats”

Questions, statements, and instructions produce different results from identical content.

Test multiple approaches:

  • Question: “What are the benefits of exercise?”
  • Statement: “Exercise has multiple benefits. Explain them.”
  • Instruction: “List 5 benefits of regular exercise with scientific backing.”
  • Role-based: “As a fitness coach, explain why clients should exercise.”

Finding: Lists, paragraphs, and dialogue formats also yield varying stability. Find what works best for your use case.

8. Mix Examples in Classification Tasks

Section titled “8. Mix Examples in Classification Tasks”

Don’t cluster all positive examples together. Randomize example order to force pattern learning, not sequence memorization.

Weak (grouped):

Strong (mixed):

Why: Models learn discriminating features when forced to distinguish between adjacent examples of different classes.

9. Adapt to Model Updates

Section titled “9. Adapt to Model Updates”

GPT-4 to GPT-4.5, Gemini 1.0 to 2.0 - prompts need recalibration.

Each model generation has different strengths, quirks, and optimal configurations. What worked yesterday may underperform today.

Best practices:

  • Re-test core prompts with each model update
  • Monitor output quality metrics over time
  • Maintain a prompt changelog
  • Keep baseline examples for comparison

Reality check: Continuous prompt optimization is not optional maintenance - it’s core product work.

10. Document Every Attempt

Section titled “10. Document Every Attempt”

Use a table to track: model, temperature, prompt, output. Three days later, you won’t remember which version worked best.

Recommended tracking fields:

FieldPurpose
ModelWhich model version
TemperatureRandomness setting
PromptExact prompt used
OutputResult received
Quality1-5 rating
NotesWhat worked/didn’t

For RAG systems: Also document which factors influenced content insertion - queries, chunking settings, and chunk outputs.

Bonus: Chain of Thought (CoT) Best Practices

Section titled “Bonus: Chain of Thought (CoT) Best Practices”

For complex reasoning tasks, set temperature to 0 for rigorous, single-answer problems requiring strict logical reasoning.

Self-Consistency Prompting: Send the same Chain-of-Thought prompt multiple times at high temperature, then “vote” on the most common final answer. This makes answers more robust and reduces hallucinations.

Step-Back Prompting: Instead of solving directly, first prompt the model to consider general principles or patterns, then use that response to guide the specific task.

The Core Insight

Section titled “The Core Insight”

All 10 practices share the same underlying logic:

LLMs are prediction engines, not reasoning engines. Every word you provide guides token prediction. Specificity reduces ambiguity. Examples outperform explanations. Positive instructions beat negative constraints.

Techniques evolve. Principles persist.

Resources

Section titled “Resources”
  • Google Prompt Engineering Whitepaper on Kaggle
  • Author: Lee Boonstra

What’s your most effective prompt engineering technique? The best prompts often come from systematic experimentation and rigorous documentation.

item.title: Quick Verification Beats Documentation: Making Codebases Agent-Ready
item.content:encoded:
Traditional software development relies on human developers to manually handle ambiguity and implicit knowledge. But AI agents are fundamentally different—they’re highly sensitive to noise and require fast, explicit, and predictable feedback loops. If your codebase lacks rigorous verification mechanisms, agents will inevitably fail in production environments.

This insight fundamentally reshapes how we should prepare our codebases for the AI-assisted development era.

The Core Insight: Tests Over Documentation

Section titled “The Core Insight: Tests Over Documentation”

Simon Willison, a respected voice in the developer community, makes a counterintuitive observation:

“I actually don’t think documentation is too important: LLMs can read the code a lot faster than you to figure out how to use it.”

This challenges the conventional wisdom that comprehensive documentation is the key to maintainable codebases. For AI agents, the calculus is different:

AspectDocumentationAutomated Tests
Feedback SpeedNone (passive reference)Immediate (active validation)
AmbiguityHigh (natural language)Low (pass/fail)
Implicit KnowledgeOften omittedEncoded in assertions
Agent UtilityCan be read, but not verifiedCan be executed and learned from

Why AI Agents Need Quick Verification

Section titled “Why AI Agents Need Quick Verification”

1. Agents Are Noise-Sensitive

Section titled “1. Agents Are Noise-Sensitive”

Unlike human developers who can filter through ambiguous instructions using context and experience, AI agents struggle with:

  • Implicit assumptions buried in code comments
  • Outdated documentation that conflicts with current behavior
  • Edge cases that aren’t mentioned anywhere

Quick verification through tests provides ground truth that agents can trust.

2. Feedback Loops Define Agent Quality

Section titled “2. Feedback Loops Define Agent Quality”

Spotify’s engineering team has extensively studied this in their background coding agents system. Their key finding:

“The verification loop allows the agent and its underlying LLM to gradually confirm it is on the right track before committing to a change.”

Their verification architecture includes:

  • Deterministic Verifiers: Automatically activated based on codebase contents (e.g., Maven verifier for pom.xml files)
  • LLM as Judge: Evaluates proposed changes against original prompts, vetoing ~25% of agent sessions
  • Course Correction: ~50% of vetoed attempts are successfully corrected by agents

3. The “Vibe Coding” Problem

Section titled “3. The “Vibe Coding” Problem”

Research from Augment Code defines “vibe coding” as accepting AI-generated code based on surface-level correctness without systematic validation. This approach:

  • Introduces security vulnerabilities in 45% of cases (according to Veracode)
  • Creates code that handles happy paths perfectly while missing error conditions
  • Leads to identical anti-patterns propagating across services

Practical Framework: 7 Validation Pillars

Section titled “Practical Framework: 7 Validation Pillars”

Based on industry research, here’s a comprehensive framework for making codebases agent-ready:

1. Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD)

Section titled “1. Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD)”

Write tests first, then let agents generate implementations:

Simon Willison’s approach: “One of my projects has 1500 tests and Claude Code is really good at selectively executing just tests relevant to the change it is making.”

2. Rich Error Messages

Section titled “2. Rich Error Messages”

This is a low-cost, high-impact improvement:

“If a manual or automated test fails, the more information you can return back to the model the better.”

Instead of:

Provide:

3. Developer Tools as Feedback Channels

Section titled “3. Developer Tools as Feedback Channels”

Configure your codebase with:

  • Linters (ESLint, Ruff, Clippy)
  • Type Checkers (TypeScript, mypy, Pyright)
  • Auto-formatters (Prettier, Black, rustfmt)

“Give coding agents helpful tools to run and they’ll use them.”

4. CI/CD Pipeline Gates

Section titled “4. CI/CD Pipeline Gates”

Implement automated validation stages:

  • Static Analysis (SAST)
  • Dynamic Testing (DAST)
  • Policy Enforcement
  • Compliance Validation

5. Observability Systems

Section titled “5. Observability Systems”

Track agent performance metrics:

  • Code quality telemetry
  • Compilation success rates
  • Test pass rates over time
  • Production behavior monitoring

6. Human Code Review (Still Essential)

Section titled “6. Human Code Review (Still Essential)”

AI frequently generates patterns with subtle integration flaws. Human reviewers catch:

  • Architectural inconsistencies
  • Security anti-patterns
  • Context-specific problems

7. Compound Learning

Section titled “7. Compound Learning”

The most advanced approach: create a learning system, not just an automation pipeline:

“Each bug, test failure, and design insight gets documented and reused by future agents, so every feature makes the next one easier to build.”

The Augmented Coding Model

Section titled “The Augmented Coding Model”

The contrast between “vibe coding” and “augmented coding” comes down to two factors:

FactorVibe CodingAugmented Coding
Feedback LoopLongerShorter
Specification LevelHigh-level, vagueDetailed, precise

For large, complex codebases, augmented coding is essential:

“You can’t simply vibe-code your way through a large and complex codebase. With augmented coding, the AI agent tackles small, clearly-defined tasks with frequent feedback loops.”

Practical Recommendations

Section titled “Practical Recommendations”

For Individual Developers

Section titled “For Individual Developers”
  1. Write tests before handing work to agents
  2. Configure comprehensive linting and type checking
  3. Provide detailed error messages in assertions
  4. Set up local dev server instructions for agents to validate UI changes

For Teams

Section titled “For Teams”
  1. Implement CI/CD gates that catch agent-generated issues
  2. Create AGENTS.md (similar to README.md) for project-specific AI guidance
  3. Document architectural decisions that aren’t obvious from code
  4. Track agent performance metrics over time

For Organizations

Section titled “For Organizations”
  1. Adopt Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD) as a standard practice
  2. Invest in observability for agent-generated code
  3. Maintain human review requirements for production deployments
  4. Build compound learning systems that improve over time

Key Takeaways

Section titled “Key Takeaways”
  1. Tests > Documentation for AI agents—they provide executable, unambiguous feedback
  2. Quick feedback loops are essential—agents need immediate validation
  3. Rich error messages are a low-cost, high-impact improvement
  4. “Vibe coding” is dangerous in enterprise environments—systematic validation is required
  5. The best practices for humans still apply—agents benefit from well-maintained codebases

The future of AI-assisted development isn’t about replacing human judgment—it’s about creating feedback-rich environments where agents can iterate quickly and humans can focus on architectural decisions and creative problem-solving.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Setting up a codebase for working with coding agents - Simon Willison
  • Background Coding Agents: Predictable Results Through Feedback Loops - Spotify Engineering
  • AI Agent Quality: 7 Frameworks to Go Beyond Vibe Coding - Augment Code
  • Coding for the Future Agentic World - Addy Osmani
